Graphical abstract Body-centered cubic (BCC) PdCu metallic aerogels (MAs) exhibit enhanced acetonitrile reduction reaction (ARR) performance with ethylamine selectivity of 90.91%, yield rate of 316.0 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu and Faradaic efficiency of 88.60% at −0.55 VRHE, outperforming the face-centered cubic PdCu MAs/C, demonstrating the important role of crystal-phase regulation in boosting ARR. The d-d orbital coupling induced by crystal-phase engineering can effectively adjust the electronic structure of electrocatalysts, thus showing significant catalytic performance, while it has been rarely explored in electrochemical acetonitrile reduction reaction (ARR) to date. Herein, we successfully realize the structural transformation of PdCu metallic aerogels (MAs) from face-centered cubic (FCC) to body-centered cubic (BCC) through annealing treatment. Specifically, the BCC PdCu MAs exhibit excellent ARR performance with high ethylamine selectivity of 90.91%, Faradaic efficiency of 88.60%, yield rate of 316.0 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu and long-term stability for consecutive electrolysis within 20 h at −0.55 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, outperforming than those of FCC PdCu MAs. Under the membrane electrode assembly system, BCC PdCu MAs also demonstrate excellent ethylamine yield rate of 389.5 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu. Density functional theory calculation reveals that the d-d orbital coupling in BCC PdCu MAs results in an evident correlation effect for the interaction of Pd and Cu sites, which boosts up the Cu sites electronic activities to enhance ARR performance. Our work opens a new route to develop efficient ARR electrocatalysts from the perspective of crystalline structure transformation. Keywords d-d Orbital coupling Crystal-phase engineering Metallic aerogels Acetonitrile electroreduction reaction Ethylamine 1 Introduction In the past decades, people have put a lot of effort into synthesizing products with high value through electrochemical technology, which is an efficient and convenient way to relieve excessive resource utilization [1–4]. Acetonitrile (CH3CN, MeCN) is one of the most frequently used ‘‘inactive’’ aprotic solvents in electrochemistry [5–7]. In different electrocatalytic environments, acetonitrile can be reduced to ethane, 3-aminobutyronitrile, NH3 and other substances [8–10]. Among the products reduced by acetonitrile, ethylamine (CH3CH2NH2, EtNH2) is an important chemical raw material and organic synthesis intermediate, which is widely used in medicine, pesticide and dye industries [11–13]. At present, there have been some reports on the acetonitrile reduction reaction (ARR). For example, Xia et al. find that when 8 wt% acetonitrile in a 1.0 M KOH solution is present, the total current density of Cu nanoparticles is 50 mA cm−2, resulting in an ethylamine Faradaic efficiency (FE) of 94.6% [14]. In addition, Zhang et al. found that the ethylamine FE during the ARR reaches 94% in a 1.0 M KHCO3 solution containing 0.5 M acetonitrile at −0.7 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) using a Cu catalyst [15]. Meanwhile, Wei et al. achieve an ethylamine FE of 97.8% at −0.32 VRHE by lattice oxygen residue mediated oxide-derived Cu (OD-Cu) nanowires [16]. These research results are all focused on achieving efficient conversion of ARR. However, during the process of ARR, the intermediate imine will continue to react with the primary amine to form secondary and tertiary amines, due to the nucleophilic nature of the intermediate imine, resulting the product a mixture of ethylamine, diethylamine, and triethylamine [17]. Previously in the thermal catalytic reaction, the complex and costly methods such as preparing primary amine by alkenes hydrogenation amination and catalysts deactivation strategy were employed to increase the selectivity of the reaction [18,19]. For this reason, the low ethylamine selectivity is still a tremendous barrier for enhanced ethylamine synthesis from acetonitrile, especially in electrochemical systems. Thus, it is full of interest and urgent to design the high-performance ARR electrocatalysts with excellent ethylamine selectivity [20]. As we all know, the critical factor to enhance the catalytic performance is to optimize the adsorption energy of the intermediate on the catalyst surface. According to reported literatures, the Cu-based catalysts would preferentially adsorb the nitrile through the C≡N group to promote the hydrogenation of acetonitrile in ARR. Meanwhile, alloying is an effective and promising method for improving efficiency and selectivity in nanomaterials, as the coupling effect brought by alloying could optimize reaction kinetics or suppress competitive reactions [21]. Inspired by this, people are committed to design Cu-based catalysts with the required size, composition and shape regulation [22–25]. Due to the high ARR activity of Pd and its diagonal position with Cu in the periodic table, its crystal structure is very similar to Cu and has a higher lattice matching degree with Cu. Therefore, when Pd and Cu interact together, they can produce better synergistic effects while avoiding the effects of lattice distortion [26–28]. Meanwhile, previous researches have mainly focused on traditional disordered Cu-based catalysts, which typically have a face-centered cubic (FCC) solid solution structure and are less stable in corrosive electrochemical environments. This is because the atoms of disordered alloy catalysts randomly occupy the FCC position and the surface atoms will rapidly dissolve into the electrolyte during the circulation of corrosive electrolyte, thus resulting in a low coordination surface and poor stability [29,30]. In order to overcome the above problems, the ordering of Cu-based catalysts is a promising strategy. When the structure of Cu-based catalysts is transformed into ordered body-centered cubic (BCC) intermetallic compounds, the activity and stability of materials would be greatly improved. Compared to disordered solid solution alloys, ordered intermetallic compounds have an orderly arrangement of atoms, which could prevent the dissolution of metal atoms and have excellent structural stability in both acidic and alkaline electrolytes [31–33]. This could be mainly due to the higher mixing enthalpy and stronger orbital interactions existing in ordered intermetallic compounds. Specifically, orbital coupling could effectively reduce the distance of electron transmission and promote the transfer of electrons from high-energy orbitals to low-energy ones, leading to changes in molecular energy bands. Except for this, it can also change the electronic structure and cause the center of the d-band to shift, thus resulting in improving the activity of the catalysts [34,35]. In addition, material design always focused on low dimensions, including zero-dimensional (0D) Cu nanoparticles, 1D Cu nanowires, and 2D Cu nanosheets for ARR. In order to expose more active sites and enhance the ARR performance, we developed Pd-Cu metallic aerogels (MAs) from a 3D perspective. As we all know, MAs have many advantages, such as rich active sites, large specific surface area, significant structural durability and abundant electron transfer channels. Furthermore, our previous work about the ARR electrocatalysts has successfully proved that MAs are a class of ideal electrocatalysts attributed to their generous active sites and excellent adsorption energy, which would efficiently enhance adsorption of acetonitrile and stabilize the imide intermediate [36–38]. Accordingly, it has aroused interest and urgency in designing high-performance ARR electrocatalysts with excellent ethylamine selectivity. Herein, in this work, we further developed a new class of BCC PdCu MAs, which would serve as the efficient and durable electrocatalysts for electrochemical ARR. Specifically, the BCC PdCu MAs show high ethylamine selectivity (90.91%), yield rate (316.0 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu), and FE (88.60%), outperforming the FCC PdCu MAs. Furthermore, BCC PdCu MAs even maintain a high ethylamine yield rate of 389.5 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu under the commercial scale membrane electrode assembly (MEA) system. Through the density functional theory (DFT) calculations, it is found that the magnanimous overlaps of Pd 4d and Cu 3d orbitals in BCC PdCu MAs induce the generation of ordered Pd-Cu-Pd bonds, thus resulting in overcoming coulomb barrier of imine intermediate (CH3CHNH*), as well as boosting the electronic exchange and transfer, to inhibit side reactions and promote hydrogenation process for excellent acetonitrile electroreduction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and chemicals These chemical reagents include sodium borohydride (NaBH4), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), ammonium chloride (NH4Cl), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), and sodium tetrachloropalladate (II) (Na2PdCl4), all of which were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). In addition, copper (II) chloride (CuCl2), ethylamine (C2H7N), and acetonitrile (C2H3N) were purchased from Titan Chemical Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Sodium citrate (NaCA) and deuterium oxide (D2O) were received from Innochem Technology Co. Ltd (Beijing, China). Meanwhile, commercial carbon powder (Vulcan XC-72) was achieved from Sinero Technology Co. Ltd (Suzhou, China). 2.2 Synthesis of PdCu MAs Firstly, NaCA (15 mmol, 3.871 g), Na2PdCl4 (0.5 mmol, 147.1 mg), CuCl2 (0.5 mmol, 67.23 mg) and NaBH4 (20 mmol, 756.6 mg) were successively added to 300 mL of water. Next, NH4Cl (10 mmol, 534.9 mg) was added to the prepared solution (300 mL) and ground for about 6 h to form an integral PdCu hydrogels. The obtained hydrogels were purified with water for 4–5 times. Finally, the wet gels were dried for 12 h by freeze-drying to obtain aerogels. 2.3 Synthesis of PdCu MAs-T/C The obtained PdCu MAs were then annealed at 250, 300, 350, 400 and 450 °C under 5% H2/95% Ar for 3 h, respectively. And the samples were denoted as PdCu MAs-250, PdCu MAs-300, PdCu MAs-350, PdCu MAs-400 and PdCu MAs-450, respectively. Then, annealed samples were mixed with commercial carbon (Vulcan XC-72) which were fixed at 25 wt%. The products were collected by centrifugation and dried naturally, which were denoted as PdCu MAs-T/C. 2.4 Characterizations The sample preparation method for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) involves using a pipette to disperse ethanol droplets on a carbon coated copper grid and drying them under environmental conditions. Under the acceleration voltage of 200 kV applied to JEOL JEM-2100F TEM, we can collect high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images, elemental mappings, and scanning TEM (STEM) images. On the Thermo Scientific Themis Z transmission electron microscope equipped with a cold field emission electron gun and a dual spherical aberration corrector, we operated at 300 kV to obtain aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained using a Linx array detector (Brooke, Germany) using Cu K α X-ray source (λ = 1.540598 Å) for collection. Scanning electron microscope energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) was captured using the Hitachi S-4800 cold field emission scanning electron microscope. We conducted X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on the Thermo Scientific K-Alpha XPS spectrometer, where the carbon peak at 284.8 eV was used as a reference for correcting the charging effect. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) and absorbance data were recorded on the Fourier infrared spectrometer (Nicolet iS50 FT-IR) in the spectral region of 500–4000 nm. To identify and quantify the yield of products in liquid electrolytes, we used 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy (AVANCE III HD). On a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, 209 F1 Libra), we analyzed the Pd loading on the catalysts using a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. We obtained relevant data on specific surface area and pore structure through Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET, Quantum Instruments U.S., Autosorb iQ) and Barrett Joyner Helenda (BJH) analysis. 2.5 Reference intensity ratio (RIR) method of quantitative analysis We used the RIR method to estimate the proportion of FCC/BCC phase in PdCu MAs/C at different treatment temperatures. For samples only containing two phases, the calculated equation is x 1 = K 2 I 1 K 2 I 1 + K 1 I 2 x 2 = K 1 I 2 K 2 I 1 + K 1 I 2 Where x i is the weight fraction of BCC or FCC phase, K i is the RIR value supplied by standard XRD card ( K F C C = 12.62; K B C C =16.94), I i is the intensity of peak of specific facet which is defined as I = 100%. 2.6 H-cell electrochemical ARR measurements The electrochemical measurement of ARR was conducted in a three-electrode battery of CHI 660e. These electrochemical measurements were conducted in a typical H-cell, which used a proton exchange membrane (PEM) (Nafion 211). The reference electrode and counter electrode are made of Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) and carbon rod, respectively. The preparation process of the working electrode was as follows: 995 μL isopropanol and 5 μL of Nafion solution (5 wt%) were used to disperse 10 mg catalysts evenly to obtain homogeneous ink. Next, 20 μL of ink was doped onto a glassy carbon electrode (diameter 5 mm, area 0.196 cm2) and dried at room temperature to obtain the working electrode. The cathode electrolysis cell contained 30 mL of 8 wt% acetonitrile solution in 1 M NaOH solution, and the anode electrolysis cell contained 30 mL of 1 M NaOH solution. 2.7 MEA electrochemical ARR measurements By using a MEA system with PEM, we can evaluate the activity of the prepared electrocatalysts on a commercial scale. This system consists of two end plates, each with a serpentine fluid channel (6.25 cm2 area, 1.0 mm width, 0.5 mm depth). To manufacture cathode electrodes, we dispersed catalysts (5 mg) in Nafion (5 wt%) (100 μL) and isopropanol (9.9 mL), and then sprayed it onto carbon paper (6.25 cm2). The catalyst load on this electrode is 0.8 mg cm−2. The anode electrode used Ni foam as a known durable catalyst. In the MEA system, we used Nafion 211 PEM to place the proton exchange membrane between the anode and cathode. Then, 1 M NaOH with 8 wt% acetonitrile was pumped to the cathode electrode channel through a peristaltic pump, while the anode electrode channel used 1 M NaOH, and setting a flow rate of 10 mL min−1. We also use the CHI 660e for measurement, clamping the working electrode at the cathode end plate, while the reference electrode and counter electrode are clamped at the anode end plate. 2.8 Product analysis Perform 1H NMR testing using AVANCE III HD 400 MHz spectrometer to study liquid products. In short, we added 200 μL of D2O as the deuterization solvent and 100 μL of 1000 ppm DMSO as the internal standard solution to 1 mL of sampled cathode electrolyte. We use the peak area ratio of ethylamine and diethylamnie to DMSO at different concentrations as the standard curve for 1H NMR testing. After completing the electrochemical test, we can calculate the ratio of ethylamine and diethylamine to DMSO in the electrolyte using 1H NMR. Then, substitute this ratio into the standard curve of ethylamine and diethylamine to calculate the yield of ethylamine and diethylamine in the electrolyte. The FE, selectivity and yield rate of product are calculated by the following equation F E = n p r o d u c t × e × F Q × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y = n p r o d u c t n t o t a l × 100 % Y i e l d r a t e = n p r o d u c t t × m P d + C u Q : quantity of electric charge integrated by the i-t curve n : the total moles of the different product F : Faraday constant, 96,485C mol−1 e : electrons transfer number m P d + C u : the amount of Pd and Cu on the electrode t : the reduction time 2.9 Computational details Vienna Ab initio simulation Simulation Package (VASP) [39] with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [40] are used for first principles calculation. In this process, Perdew Burke ernzerhof (PBE) functional combined with DFT-D correction is used to process the exchange functional [41]. The calculation is carried out in spin polarization mode, and the cut-off energy of the plane wave base is set to 450 eV. In order to optimize the geometric structure and lattice size, 2*2*1 Monkhorts-Pack [42] K point sampling is used in surface sampling, and 3*3*3 is used in volume sampling. Moreover, 7*7*7 is set for the DOS calculation. In the self consistent calculation, the convergence energy threshold is set to 10−5 eV, and the equilibrium geometry and lattice constant are optimized to ensure that the maximum stress on each atom is in the range of 0.02 eV Å−1. In order to consider the influence of spin polarization, Vaspkit [43] is also used to get the DOS data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electrocatalyst preparation and structural characterization A facile salt-gelation method was employed to prepare FCC PdCu MAs (wherein feed ratio of Pd/Cu = 1/1) after freeze-drying. As shown in Fig. S1(a and b), the cross-linked structure of FCC PdCu MAs was revealed by TEM and SEM [44]. According to the SEM-EDS analysis, the atomic ratio of Pd and Cu is 45.09/54.91 (Fig. S1c). Through the XRD pattern (Fig. S1d), it could be found that the representative diffraction peaks appearing at 41.4°, 48.2°, and 70.5° correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) facets of FCC PdCu (JCPDS No.48–1551). In addition, HRTEM observation shows a lattice spacing of 0.218 nm, which is very consistent with the (111) facet of FCC PdCu alloy (Fig. S1e). By HAADF-STEM and corresponding EDS elemental mappings, it can be clearly seen that Pd and Cu uniformly distribute in PdCu MAs (Fig. S1f). In addition, FCC PdCu MAs also possess a high specific surface area (SA) of 63.52 m2 g−1 (Fig. S1g). After annealing FCC PdCu MAs in a 5%/95% H2/Ar atmosphere at 400 °C for 3 h, the BCC PdCu MAs were successfully obtained (Fig. 1 a). Except for the diffraction peaks of FCC PdCu, there are some new diffraction peaks appeared in BCC PdCu MAs. Based on XRD patterns, we confirm that these new diffraction peaks of 30.1°, 43.1°, 62.6° and 78.9° are correspond to the (100), (110), (220), and (211) facets of BCC PdCu (ICDD No. 01-078-4406) [45]. Then, we used the RIR quantitative analysis method through XRD patterns to monitor structural changes and determine the proportion of FCC/BCC phases [46,47]. As shown in Fig. S2, when the temperature rises to 250 °C (PdCu MAs-250), the FCC phase begins to transform into BCC phase, with an FCC/BCC structure ratio of 91.75%/8.25%. As the temperature continues to rise to 300 °C (PdCu MAs-300) and 350 °C (PdCu MAs-350), the FCC phase partially transforms into BCC phase, which gradually dominates. As for PdCu MAs-300 and PdCu MAs-350, the FCC/BCC structural ratios are 42.35%/57.65% and 33.32%/66.68%, respectively. When the annealing temperature is 400 °C (PdCu MAs-400), FCC PdCu MAs are mostly converted to BCC PdCu MAs, where the FCC/BCC structure ratio is 8.57%/91.43%. With the annealing temperature arriving at 450 °C (PdCu MAs-450), the FCC/BCC structure ratio is 5.42%/94.58%, which is close to that at 400 °C (PdCu MAs-400), indicating that there is no obvious phase transition process and the phase transition has stabilized. As shown in Fig. 1(b and c), the BCC PdCu MAs (PdCu MAs-400) can still maintain a highly cross-linked structure of MAs. In addition, we can observe that the lattice spacing of PdCu MAs-400 is 0.208 nm through the aberration corrected HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 1d), which corresponds to the (110) facet of BCC PdCu MAs. Compared with the 0.218 nm lattice spacing of (111) facet in FCC PdCu, the lattice spacing is significantly shortened, resulting in a decrease in the structural period of the lattice, enhancing the stability of the crystal structure [33]. When we observe along the axis of the [001] region, a well patterned periodic square array of stacked sequence atoms is formed on entire sample. Meanwhile, this periodic ordering is demonstrated using fast Fourier transform (FFT) plots, where the {100} spots of BCC PdCu are shown in Fig. 1(d) (inset) [48,49]. In addition, through the ordered arrangement of Pd and Cu atoms with different contrasts, we can observe this structure in Fig. 1(e). At the same time, the periodic fluctuation of the line intensity distribution proves that two different types of atoms appear alternately (Fig. 1f). The corresponding EDS elemental mappings (Fig. 1g) also show that Pd and Cu atoms distribute uniformly on PdCu MAs-400. Therefore, BCC PdCu is a primitive cubic structure composed of periodic matrices of Pd and Cu atoms, with these atoms locating at the corners and center of each cell, while the atomic positions of FCC PdCu are randomly occupied by Pd and Cu atoms. Meanwhile, the energy generated during high-temperature annealing could reduce the atomic diffusion barrier, increase atomic mobility, and promote orderly arrangement, which is very beneficial for the formation of ordered intermetallic nanocrystals, thus optimizing the structure and performance of nanocrystals. While, BCC PdCu MAs exhibit a lower surface area (52.27 m2 g−1) comparable to FCC PdCu (63.52 m2 g−1), which attributing to the inevitable increase in grain size during the hot annealing process (Fig. 1h). 3.2 Electrocatalytic ARR performance Before electrocatalytic measurement, PdCu MAs, PdCu MAs-300, PdCu MAs-400 and PdCu MAs-450 were chosen to be loaded on carbon powder (Vulcan XC-72), named as PdCu MAs-T/C (T = 300, 400, and 450, Figs. S3–S6) [50]. As illustrated in Fig. S7, the loading amount of Pd in PdCu MAs-T/C was confirmed by TG analysis from room temperature to 900 °C in O2. And then, electrochemical surface area (ECSA) of the different electrocatalysts was detected by CO stripping (Fig. S8) to reflect the actual active area of the catalyst involved in the catalytic process [51–53]. PdCu MAs-400/C have the largest ECSA of 56.38 m2 g−1 among the four different electrocatalysts, indicating more exposed active sites. The difference between the CO stripping and BET results could be attributed to different goals pursued of the two tests. The electrochemical ARR performance of different PdCu MAs-T/C was studied by an H-cell with a three-electrode system in 1 M NaOH containing 8 wt% acetonitrile [16]. All potentials are reported based on the RHE (Fig. S9). As vividly shown in Fig. 2 (a), the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves show that PdCu MAs-400/C have the maximum current density of 49.83 mA cm−2 at −0.65 VRHE among the different PdCu MAs-T/C catalysts, which is 3.14, 1.73 and 1.43 times higher than that of PdCu MAs/C (15.86 mA cm−2), PdCu MAs-300/C (28.84 mA cm−2) and PdCu MAs-450/C (34.81 mA cm−2), exhibiting a stronger response to acetonitrile over PdCu MAs-400/C. As shown in Figs. S10 and S11, we also quantified liquid products to estimate ethylamine selectivity, yield, and FE through 1H NMR analysis. As observed in Fig. 2(b and c), the optimal PdCu MAs-400/C exhibit the maximum ethylamine selectivity (90.91%), yield rate (316.0 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu) and FE (88.60%), which are higher than those of PdCu MAs/C (75.68 %, 162.6 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu, 69.30%), PdCu MAs-300/C (79.60%, 186.8 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu, 81.93%) and PdCu MAs-450/C (86.36%, 289.5 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu, 89.69%) (Fig. 2d–f and Figs. S12 and S13), indicating that the performance of ARR depends on the structural differences of FCC and BCC structure and as the increasing proportion of BCC, the electrocatalytic performance is significantly enhanced. However, with the temperature arriving at 450 °C, the ARR performance represents obvious decrease. It could be attributed to the fact that the increase in annealing temperature is beneficial for accelerating atomic migration and promoting atomic arrangement, but at the same time, higher annealing temperature can cause Oswald ripening, leading to an increase in the size and uneven distribution of nanocrystals, thus reducing the catalytic performance of the catalysts, which is in line with the above electron microscope results. In addition, through the 1H NMR spectra, we can see that the liquid products are mainly ethylamine and diethylamine, and there is a competitive relationship between ethylamine and diethylamine. If we can inhibit the production of diethylamine, the electrochemical performance of ethylamine would be effectively increased. Therefore, to accurately evaluate the performance of ARR, FE and selectivity of diethylamine were calculated in Figs. S14 and S15, and the highest FE and selectivity of diethylamine for PdCu MAs-400/C are only 11.38% and 11.53%, which are lower than the other catalysts at most potentials, reflecting that PdCu MAs-400/C possess excellent selectivity and catalytic activity for ethylamine. Such results could be clarified that ordered crystal structure not only provides fast channels for electron transfer, but also optimizes the adsorption capacity of intermediates, thereby enhancing the adsorption capacity of imine intermediates. This enhanced adsorption ability can enable the imine intermediate to adsorb more stably on the surface, effectively preventing the imine intermediate from continuing to react with ethylamine to generate diethylamine, thus maintaining high selectivity in the reaction. Meanwhile, due to the inevitable competition of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the current density of the obtained LSV cannot be fully attributed to ARR. To clarify that the current density comes from the ARR process instead of HER, we further advanced our research by calculating the partial current density of electrocatalysts prepared at different potentials. As observed in Fig. 2(g), the partial current density of ethylamine on PdCu MAs-400/C can reach 13.64 mA cm−2 at −0.55 VRHE, which is approximately twice that of FCC PdCu MAs/C (6.92 mA cm−2). At the same time, under all applied potentials, the partial current density of ethylamine on PdCu MAs-400/C is higher than that of other compounds. In addition, at −0.55 VRHE, the current density of PdCu MAs-400/C can remain unchanged for 20 h (Fig. 2h), while the current intensity in PdCu MAs/C gradually decreases by 45.90%. Besides, after the durability test, the change of the cross-linked structure, composition and electronic structure of the BCC PdCu MAs is negligible (Fig. S16), demonstrating the remarkable durability of BCC structure, which could serve as an efficient and stable catalyst in ARR electrocatalytic experiments. In addition, we have compared the performance of several catalysts we designed with those previously reported, and found that PdCu MAs-400/C still show excellent performance (Table S1). Under experimental conditions, it could be found that PdCu MAs-400/C exhibit excellent catalytic performance and durability for ARR. Based on a reasonable initial potential selection at laboratory scale, we further evaluate the commercial scale ARR performance of PdCu MAs-400/C in MEA system (Fig. 3 a), meanwhile, the PdCu MAs/C were taken as a comparison. The MEA system is composed of end plates with serpentine fluid channels (6.25 cm2), membrane electrodes and PEM (Nafion 211). In this system, the cathode membrane electrode was formed by spraying electrocatalysts we designed on carbon paper, and the anode membrane electrode was directly made of Ni foam. At the same time, we used a peristaltic pump to transport with/without 8 wt% acetonitrile in 1 M NaOH electrolyte to the cathode/anode at a rate of 10 mL min−1. Through the LSV result (Fig. 3b), it demonstrates that the current density of PdCu MAs-400/C is 57.74 mA cm−2 at −1.80 V, nearly 2.6 times larger than that of PdCu MAs/C (21.72 mA cm−2). To further estimate the electrochemical performance of ethylamine over the FCC and BCC MAs, we conducted electrolytic measurements from −1.60 to −1.80 V (Fig. 3c and d). As shown in Fig. 3(e and f), especially at −1.80 V, PdCu MAs-400/C achieve a maximum ethylamine selectivity of 94.36% and a yield of 389.5 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu, better than those of PdCu MAs/C (75.44% and 132.2 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu). Furthermore, PdCu MAs-400/C also exhibit the higher ethylamine FE at the various potentials relative to PdCu MAs/C (Fig. 3g). The ethylamine FE of PdCu MAs-400/C reaches the highest value of 48.37% at −1.80 V, while the ethylamine FE of PdCu MAs/C is only 34.82%. Above all, we find that with the increase of applied potential, the ARR performance of two different electrocatalysts was improved, and there is competition for HER at the lower potential in aqueous electrolyte. Then we further calculated the partial current density at different potentials to reflect the actual electrocatalytic situation of ARR (Fig. 3h). It is clearly revealed that PdCu MAs-400/C exhibit the higher partial current densities at all the applied potentials than those of PdCu MAs/C, and reach 28.83 mA cm−2 at −1.80 V, which is 2.7 times higher than PdCu MAs/C (10.75 mA cm−2). In summary, even in MEA system, PdCu MAs-400/C still exhibit better ARR performance than PdCu MAs/C, further demonstrating the important role of MAs structures with BCC phase in improving ARR performance. 3.3 Investigation of the catalytic mechanisms Due to the special catalytic activity of BCC PdCu MAs nanostructures, XPS studies were performed to analyze their electronic structure (Figs. S17 and S18). The Pd 3d spectrum of PdCu MAs-T/C shows two peaks, corresponding to Pd 3d 5/2 and Pd 3d 3/2, respectively. These two peaks further split into two double peaks, which are related to the chemical states of Pd0 and Pd2+. In likewise, the Cu 2p spectrum also shows two peaks of Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, which can be decomposed into the forms of Cu0 and Cu2+ [54]. After the thermal treatment, the ratio of Cu0/Cu2+ in PdCu MAs-400/C increases, while the corresponding Pd0/Pd2+ ratio has not undergone significant changes. A higher Cu0 ratio can increase the number of free Cu sites in PdCu MAs-400/C and improve the catalytic performance of reaction molecules in contact with these sites. Specifically, the increase in the proportion of metal atoms effectively enhances the interaction between atoms. At the same time, the exposure of more active sites can help alleviate the decrease in catalytic performance caused by excessive adsorption of reactant molecules on the surface of active sites. In addition, compared with the binding energy (BE) in PdCu MAs-T/C, electron transfer would occur due to the differences in electronegativity between elements. Specifically, the BE of Cu exhibits positive migration towards higher energy, indicating a lack of localized electrons. However, the BE of Pd shows a negative shift, indicating an increase in local electron density [55]. This situation confirms the strong local electron transfer between Cu and Pd atoms. Such similar phenomena can also be seen in the other PdCu MAs-T/C (Figs. S19 and S20). The degree of changes in BE further improves with the increase of annealing temperature, which can be explained by the crystal-phase adjustment. Annealing promotes atomic rearrangement, leading to a more ordered crystal structure and a significant change in electronic structure, thus enhancing the interaction between atoms and improving catalytic performance. Compared with the crystal plane spacing of FCC close-packed surface (111), the crystal plane spacing of BCC close-packed surface becomes smaller, indicating that the array is sparse [54]. On the other hand, the change of crystal structure expands the channel of electron transmission, thus accelerating the process of electron transfer. Through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) (Fig. S21), we further analyze the electron transport capacity. The results clearly explain that PdCu MAs-400/C have a low charge transfer resistance in a corrosive environment, indicating its rapid electron transfer capability. Its attributes to the atoms can be rearranged to form a more ordered BCC structure after annealing, providing a fast channel for electron transport, thereby increasing current density and enhancing catalytic activity [56,57]. At the same time, the exposure of active sites can absorb more reaction intermediates, thus enhancing the catalytic activity of the materials. In order to further investigate the adsorption capacity of different electrocatalysts, we used FT-IR analysis. According to Fig. 4 (a) and Fig. S22, we find that the absorption peak of imine (–C = N–) is located at 1632 cm−1. In addition, the transmittance values of PdCu MAs/C (94.10%) and PdCu MAs-400/C (90.77%) after catalysis are lower than those before catalysis (PdCu MAs/C (97.30%) and PdCu MAs-400/C (96.91%)), indicating that BCC PdCu MAs would adsorb more imine than FCC PdCu MAs [6,58]. These results are consistent with the results of XPS, and the enhanced adsorption ability makes PdCu MAs-400/C more active during ARR. Besides, as vividly shown in Fig. S23, the N 1s XPS spectra can be divided into three peaks for = N–, –NH– and –N+–, and the main peak for FCC PdCu is = N–, while the main peak of BCC PdCu is –NH–. Then we calculated the ratio of = N– and –NH– to display the conversion ability of ethylamine (–NH–), and the value of FCC PdCu and BCC PdCu is 2.04 and 0.19. Such results indicate that the surface area of FCC PdCu accumulates a large number of unconverted imine intermediates (=N–), indicating that it is difficult to continue hydrogenation for FCC PdCu. While BCC PdCu can convert more imine intermediates into ethylamine, exhibiting excellent ARR performance. To better understand the structure–activity relationship between crystal structure, electronic structure, and catalytic performance of BCC PdCu and FCC PdCu, we operated the projected partial density of states (PDOS) based on DFT calculation (Fig. 4b) [59]. The 3d orbitals of Cu can be divided into t2g and eg, and the t2g-eg splitting interval of the Cu 3d orbitals in FCC PdCu was calculated to be 0.47 eV, while the t2g-eg gap of the Cu 3d band in BCC PdCu is significantly shortened (only 0.21 eV). The shortening of the gap between Cu 3d orbitals could be attributed to the electron occupation of Pd 4d orbitals (shadow in gray). If the PDOS of two atoms that are spatially close have overlapping peaks in certain energy ranges, then the two atoms are bonded. There is a significant overlap between the Pd 4d orbitals and the Cu 3d orbitals in the gray shadow of BCC PdCu (d-d orbital coupling), while there exists only a small overlap with Pd 4d orbitals in the gray shaded portion of FCC PdCu, which makes a little contribution to the total density of states (TDOS). At the same time, we observe that the Cu 3d orbital from BCC PdCu is well arranged between the two main peaks of Pd 4d orbital, which indicates that there is an ordered Pd–Cu–Pd bond in BCC PdCu and an effective electron transfer. In addition, the Fermi energy levels and d-band center positions of FCC PdCu and BCC PdCu were calculated respectively [60,61]. We find that the PdCu phase transition from FCC (1.460 eV) to BCC (1.102 eV) leads to an upward shift of the d-band center, resulting in the d-band center in BCC PdCu moving closer to the Fermi level. According to the d-band center theory, the closer the center of the d-band is to the Fermi level, the higher the central energy level of the d-band is, which enhances the adsorption capacity between the surface and the intermediate [62,63]. Therefore, the orbital coupling of Pd (4d) and Cu (3d) changes the atomic spacing and electronic structure between Pd and Cu atoms, makes the center of the d-band closer to the Fermi energy level, and enhances the binding energy between the surface atom and the reactant, thus resulting in the excellent activity of BCC PdCu for ARR. In order to gain a deeper understanding of the mechanism on the different PdCu MAs during ARR, the (110) surface of BCC PdCu and the (111) surface of FCC PdCu were selected as the model catalysts, respectively. Fig. 4(c) illustrates the reaction pathway and corresponding energy distribution of FCC PdCu and BCC PdCu. Initially, CH3CN is adsorbed to the Cu site through N-terminal bonding in the top configuration, followed by hydrogenation at the C-terminal to form the intermediate CH3CHN*. Subsequently, additional hydrogenation reactions can occur at the N position to generate CH3CHNH*. Further hydrogenation reactions then take place at both C and N sites, resulting in the formation of a primary amine (CH3CH2NH2*), which binds to atom via its N terminal. The final product is desorbed from the surface through the bond dissociation. In comparison with FCC PdCu, BCC PdCu exhibits a more stable overall reaction path with lower Gibbs free energy values, indicating that ARR on BCC PdCu is thermodynamically more favorable. The binding affinity between FCC PdCu and CH3C x N y * intermediate is relatively weak, leading to higher free energy barriers throughout the process. The potential determining step (PDS) involves the adsorption of CH3CH2NH* (0.62 eV) for FCC PdCu, suggesting that it is challenging for FCC PdCu to continue hydrogenation after adsorbing imine intermediate. And the total free energy required for FCC PdCu to adsorb imine intermediates amounts to 0.61 eV, which exceeds 0.35 eV needed for BCC PdCu. It has been demonstrated that BCC structure facilitates of imine intermediates and enables continuous hydrogenation reactions towards primary amine production. The stronger towards imine intermediates prevents their condensation reaction with free ethylamine molecules while promoting efficient electroreduction of acetonitrile. In addition, the Gibbs free energy required for conversion from imine intermediate (CH3CHNH*) to diethylamine ((CH3CH2)2NH*) was calculated in order to analyze ARR pathway in detail (corresponding adsorption models are shown in Fig. S24). The energy barrier from CH3CHNH* to (CH3CH2)2NH* in BCC PdCu is 1.17 eV, which is approximately 0.07 eV higher than that in FCC PdCu, indicating that BCC PdCu requires more energy for the conversion of diethylamine and is more likely to produce ethylamine. Additionally, both FCC PdCu and BCC PdCu possess distinct lattice structures and surface arrangements, leading to variations in their adsorption capacities towards different molecules (Fig. 4d). Notably, CH3CN molecules (0.93 eV) and CH3CHNH* (1.21 eV) exhibit high adsorption energies on BCC PdCu. Conversely, FCC PdCu demonstrates lower adsorption energies for CH3CN molecules (0.67 eV) and CH3CHNH* (0.94 eV), making it challenging for them to be effectively adsorbed and subsequently hydrogenated during the reaction process. Furthermore, the lower adsorption energy of CH3CH2NH* (0.72 eV) on BCC PdCu further supports that BCC PdCu possesses lower adsorption energy for diethylamine, making it more prone to ARR. In conclusion, due to the difference in adsorption energy, BCC PdCu shows higher ARR catalytic performance. Accordingly, based on the DFT results, we can reasonably propose the mechanism of ethylamine formation on FCC PdCu and BCC PdCu (Fig. 4e). Acetonitrile molecules are first adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts, and then the acetonitrile molecules transform into imine intermediate (2e−) and ethylamine (4e−) through a gradual hydrogenation reaction. As for FCC PdCu, due to the random occupation of FCC sites by Pd and Cu atoms, the irregular crystal structure arrangement generates higher hydrogenation energy barriers, which hinders the efficiency of the imine intermediate to continue the reaction to generate ethylamine. At the same time, there is no coupling effect between the Pd 4d orbitals and the Cu 3d orbitals, resulting in insufficient adsorption capacity for imine intermediates, leading to their continued condensation reaction with free ethylamine molecules. It is worth noting that, benefiting from the formation of Pd–Cu–Pd bonding induced by Pd–Cu d-d orbital coupling in BCC PdCu, which makes the center of the d-band of BCC PdCu shift closer to the Fermi level, thus changing the electronic structure and enhancing the binding energy of surface atoms with reactants and intermediates. By adsorbing the free imine intermediate, it could be further hydrogenated to produce ethylamine, thus improving the yield. In this process, the primary amine can not only be protected, but also improve the selectivity of ethylamine. This is because it prevents the reaction between imine intermediates and free ethylamine molecules, so that the primary amine remains unchanged in the reaction and improves the selectivity and yield of ethylamine. Therefore, adsorption of free imine intermediates plays an important role in the production of ethylamine, which has more advantages than other methods. 4 Conclusions In general, we successfully prepared PdCu MAs with cross-linked network structure, and realized the structural transition from FCC to BCC via thermal treatment for the first time. The BCC phase PdCu MAs-400/C are proved to be an active and stable ARR electrocatalyst, which achieve the high ethylamine selectivity of 90.91%, yield rate of 316.0 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu and FE of 88.60% at −0.55 VRHE, outperforming the FCC PdCu MAs/C, and PdCu MAs-400/C also show durable electrochemical stability for consecutive electrolysis within 20 h. Moreover, the PdCu MAs-400/C exhibit high selectivity (94.36%), FE (48.37%) and yield rate (389.5 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu) of ethylamine in MEA system for commercial scale test. It is found that the ordered arrangement of atoms in BCC PdCu MAs provides a channel for electron transfer, which accelerates the electron transfer in the ARR process. Moreover, DFT calculation shows that the strong d-d coupling between Pd 4d and Cu 3d orbital is conducive to the transfer of electrons between different positions, which is favor for the ARR reaction. Our findings provide new insights into crystal-phase engineering and open up a new way to design ARR electrocatalysts with excellent activity, selectivity and stability. coredata.dc:description: The d-d orbital coupling induced by crystal-phase engineering can effectively adjust the electronic structure of electrocatalysts, thus showing significant catalytic performance, while it has been rarely explored in electrochemical acetonitrile reduction reaction (ARR) to date. Herein, we successfully realize the structural transformation of PdCu metallic aerogels (MAs) from face-centered cubic (FCC) to body-centered cubic (BCC) through annealing treatment. Specifically, the BCC PdCu MAs exhibit excellent ARR performance with high ethylamine selectivity of 90.91%, Faradaic efficiency of 88.60%, yield rate of 316.0 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu and long-term stability for consecutive electrolysis within 20 h at −0.55 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode, outperforming than those of FCC PdCu MAs. Under the membrane electrode assembly system, BCC PdCu MAs also demonstrate excellent ethylamine yield rate of 389.5 mmol h−1 g−1 Pd+Cu. Density functional theory calculation reveals that the d-d orbital coupling in BCC PdCu MAs results in an evident correlation effect for the interaction of Pd and Cu sites, which boosts up the Cu sites electronic activities to enhance ARR performance. Our work opens a new route to develop efficient ARR electrocatalysts from the perspective of crystalline structure transformation.
